body: The Q train from which a 3-year-old Brooklyn boy fell on Tuesday was certified in good working order a little more than a month ago, transit officials said yesterday, as questions resurfaced about whether the end doors on all subway cars should be locked. The boy, Austin Mei, who was flung from the train he was riding with his mother when the car
title: Subway Train In Fatal Fall Passed a Check In October

body: The Q train from Brooklyn to Manhattan was crowded yesterday morning, but Xing Ling Mei managed to get a seat at the end of a car with her son Austin, 3. The boy sat on his mother's lap at first, then stood up. Ms. Mei ordered him to sit back down as the train left the DeKalb Avenue station. As the train rounded a curve, the metal door leading from
title: Fall From Subway Train Kills 3-Year-Old Boy

body: After years of false starts, East New York is pinning its hopes for economic resurrection on a 230-acre Brooklyn landfill. For decades, the land and scores of other vacant lots helped earn the battered Brooklyn neighborhood a reputation as a hard-luck ghetto, a place where nothing grew but weeds and the crime rate. But now this huge tract of land
title: East New York Senses Promise In a New Mall

body: For the first time since it required tougher English tests for high school graduation, the State Board of Regents has released scores that capture the progress of an entire class. The data presented here are for New York City students who entered ninth grade for the first time in fall 1996. To reflect that many students did not make it to senior
title: How High School Students Did on the Regents Exams

Lazio resorted to invective and abusive attacks that centered on the bombing of the destroyer Cole. Mrs. Clinton began broadcasting a television advertisement that opens
title: Clinton and Lazio Turn Negative On Campaign Use of Cole Attack

body: As Tino Martinez's glove snapped shut on the final out, the stars clicked into alignment in the sporting firmament above New York and a constellation that had not been seen in 44 years lighted up the skies of a city deliciously and deliriously divided against itself. The Yankees and the Mets. Timeless pinstripes vs. suddenly fashionable blue and
title: BASEBALL: 2000 PLAYOFFS; A City Happily Pitted Against Itself

body: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Democratic candidate for vice president, said yesterday that he was apparently not related to Hillel Lieberman, an American-born settler killed last weekend in the violence between Israelis and Palestinians on the West Bank. Hillel Lieberman's father, Rabbi Sidney Zvulun Lieberman, of Congregation Beth Torah in
title: Lieberman Finds No Relation to Settler Killed in West Bank

body: As Yom Kippur worshipers at Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel in the Riverdale section of the Bronx filed out of services at midday yesterday, two police detectives and an agent from the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms combed the building's perimeter and the woodsy area around it. They examined windows and poked through leaves and
title: Tragedy in Israel and Vandalism Here Darken Yom Kippur

body: A distant cousin of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman who had lived in Israel for 15 years was found slain in a gully near the West Bank town of Nablus over the weekend after being abducted by Palestinian rioters as he tried to defend a Jewish holy site they were demolishing, Israeli and American officials said. The body of the victim, Hillel Lieberman,
title: WHOSE HOLY LAND? A CASUALTY; Cousin of Senator Lieberman Is Kidnapped and Killed During West Bank Violence

body: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: FOSTER CARE CASE SET FOR TRIAL A federal judge in Manhattan has ruled that a trial is needed to determine whether the city and a foster care agency deprived a father of due process by failing to notify him that his missing son had been in city foster care for years. The lawsuit involves a limousine driver, Hardaway H., and his
title: METRO BRIEFING

body: Friday night at the fights usually means rich guys at ringside watching a couple of street toughs battle it out. But once a month at Gleason's Gym in Brooklyn, it's the other way around. On a recent Friday, the lean, gritty fighters who train regularly at the gym laid off the speed bags to watch the fancy-pants fighters trying out their footwork in
title: Brooklyn Journal; The Suits Put Up Dukes Ali's Old Boxing Gym

title: Paid Notice: Deaths SOLOMON, ESTHER

body: The year was 1936, and President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia, along with 7,500 guests, had turned out to lay a cornerstone at Brooklyn College, a W.P.A. project that was under construction on a graceful ivy-covered campus in the heart of Midwood. But amid all the brass bands and hoopla, no one recorded the fact that a time
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDWOOD; 1936, Stored in Stone, Is Relived at Brooklyn College

body: Bill Hannan rushed for three touchdowns and returned an interception 55 yards for another score to help Garden City defeat Hewlett, 24-12. Garden City managed to win without its starting quarterback, Dave Kang, who has an injured ankle. The junior quarterback Steve DeGrazia, who was 7 of 11 in passing for 93 yards and a touchdown, filled in
title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Hannan's Two-Way Effort Leads Way for Garden City

title: Brooklyn Journal; For Orthodox, a Garden for Courting

title: Paid Notice: Deaths ALEXANDER, CLAIRE

body: A RIOT of color and a burst of energy hit the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center last week when the Accent on Design Show came to town. Child-friendly plastic stools, bright children's chairs and affordable hand-blown glass vases in a rainbow of colors are just a few of the new designs that were shown. Some of the high-voltage energy came from the
title: CURRENTS: ACCENT ON DESIGN; Housewares With the Energy of Youth

body: A volunteer ambulance responding to a call from a woman with chest pains Sunday night collided with a motorcycle, killing a father and his 13-year-old son, the police said. Alberto Curtis, 37, and his son Alberto Jr. were riding a motorcycle south on Ocean Avenue in Midwood, Brooklyn, when they struck a station wagon with ambulance license plates
title: Brooklyn Ambulance Crash Kills Father and 13-Year-Old Son

body: ELTON-William R. (Professor). Loving son of the late Mollie and William Ribakoff. Devoted brother of Mildred Boyd and Sylvia Gans. He was an accomplished poet, a respected scholar and an esteemed member of the faculty of the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. His
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ELTON, WILLIAM R. (PROFESSOR)

body: Lena Cymbrowitz, a first-term state assemblywoman from Brooklyn, died yesterday in Manhattan. She was 43. Her family said she had been ill for a long time, but gave no details. Ms. Cymbrowitz, a Democrat, represented the 45th District, which includes Sheepshead Bay, Manhattan Beach, Gerritsen Beach and parts of Flatbush, Midwood and Brighton Beach.
title: Lena Cymbrowitz -- Brooklyn Assemblywoman, 43

author: Samuel G. Freedman is a journalism professor at Columbia. This article is adapted from ''Jew vs. Jew,'' to be published this month by Simon & Schuster.
body: Divided by allegiance and an aisle, David Gottesman and Si Wachsberger awaited the vote of the Beachwood, Ohio, Planning and Zoning Commission on agenda item 96-63. Normally, half a dozen spectators might sit through the commission's business of density, setbacks and demolition permits. Tonight 400 packed the recreation room of City Hall,
title: The Jewish Tipping Point

body: EVER since they bought it in 1967, Pete and Niki Spanakos have enjoyed living in their brilliantly white all-steel house in Sea Gate, Brooklyn. The beachfront house, believed to have been designed in 1936 by William Van Alen, architect of the Chrysler Building, is known in the neighborhood as ''the sugar cube.'' Now that their children are grown,
title: Streetscapes/Sea Gate, Brooklyn; Beachfront House, Shining White and Made of Steel

body: WANT to bring a room of preservationists to a rolling boil? Just say two words: ''vinyl siding.'' In many communities you'll see plenty of nice old houses cloaked with vinyl, aluminum and asphalt coverings. It's just the kind of thing historic district regulations are designed to prevent, and even dedicated vinyl lovers in historic districts don't
title: Streetscapes/245 Fenimore Street in the Prospect Lefferts Gardens Historic District; Two Opposing Sides in the Debate Over Vinyl Siding

title: Free Market Comes To Lower East Side; As Co-op Price Caps Are Lifted, Some Residents Are Wary of Change

title: The Smart Set

body: IT sounds like something out of ancient mythology. Three brothers living near the edge of a forest witness the coming of an invading army. title: Heroes Among Us

body: WHEN girls from around New York City, juniors in public schools, sat down to write about ''A Woman I Admire'' they chose subjects as celebrated as Princess Di, as memorable as Hester Prynne and as ancient as Eve. But many of the girls, in an annual essay contest sponsored by Barnard College and the CBS Foundation, wrote about mothers: mothers who
title: FIRST PERSON; M Is For . . .

body: The moment was three years in the planning for Carol Fazio, the nurse manager at the Kings Highway Division of the Beth Israel Medical Center. To celebrate, she passed out tiny plastic Rollerblade keychains from a paper bag. ''It's nurse appreciation day,'' she joked. ''I bought you a new E.R.'' ''Roller skates? We need more than roller skates,''
title: Hospital's Move Gives Staff Room to Breathe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths DUPONG, WILLIAM G.

title: PLUS: TRACK AND FIELD -- MIDWOOD INVITATIONAL; 800-Meter Run Ends in a Tie

body: NO getting away from it: everywhere in New York City home prices just keep climbing -- from the rarefied heights of Manhattan where 11 apartments have sold for $10 million or more so far this year, compared with just six in all of 1999, to every single ZIP code area in the city's other boroughs. title: In All 5 Boroughs, High Goes Higher

body: A few months ago, narcotics detectives in Brooklyn began to swarm about a tree-lined stretch of Rugby Road about a mile south of Prospect Park. Their main target was Jose Sierra, a short, chunky 32-year-old with a gold tooth who lives with his wife and three children in a $400-a-month apartment at the intersection of Rugby Road and Newkirk Avenue.

title: Words Hidden in DNA Win Intel Competition

title: Beyond the Pale of the M.T.A.; On City-Run Buses, Getting to Work Can Be Work

title: Far From Politics, School Life Goes On; Who's In? Who's Out? I.S. 62 Has Better Things to Worry About

title: Distribution of Vouchers For Day Care Is Scrutinized

title: In Science Competitions, Every Player Wins

body: Viviana Ioana Risca, a high school senior in Port Washington, N.Y., knows how to keep a secret. She knows so much that she became one of 40 national finalists in the Intel Science Talent Search, the most prestigious high school science competition in the country, officials announced yesterday. In her study of steganography, the science of
title: Search for Science Talent Homes In on Long Island

body: The city's Department of Investigation is examining a city subsidy program that has awarded a disproportionate share of day care benefits to Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn, officials said yesterday. The investigation, first reported yesterday in The Daily News and in Newsday, has focused on the distribution of thousands of vouchers used by parents to
title: City Investigates Program, Citing Disproportionate Granting of Day Care Benefits

title: IN BRIEF; Port Washington Leads The Intel Science List

title: THE NEDIEST CASES; Off the Street and Back in High School

title: BULLTIN BOARD

title: Brooklyn Man Charged in Terror Plot Is Held Without Bond
